feed.title: Against Allowing Quantum Recovery of Bitcoin

entry.title: Against Allowing Quantum Recovery of Bitcoin
entry.summary:
The discussion revolves around the implications of potential lawsuits against developers for protocol changes within a decentralized network, such as Bitcoin. It challenges the notion that developers could be held liable for any losses resulting from these changes, arguing that such a perspective overlooks the actual enforcement mechanisms of the protocol. Enforcement is carried out by miners and node operators, not the developers themselves, making it difficult for legal actions to target the correct parties. Furthermore, the idea of suing based on the dislike of software runs counter to principles of freedom of speech, at least in the United States, highlighting the protection afforded to developers under such rights.
The concept of trust within the Bitcoin network is also examined. While Bitcoin operates on a trustless basis by allowing individuals to independently verify the state of the network through their full nodes, there remains an inherent need to trust other network participants not to coordinate detrimental changes. The narrative suggests that even if a supermajority of the network's sovereign actors decided to implement protective measures against quantum-capable adversaries, the threat of legal action is unlikely to deter them. This underscores the decentralized nature of Bitcoin and the complex interplay between trust, autonomy, and the legal landscape surrounding technological innovation.
